title: How to Add Fractions with Whole Numbers: Student Tutorial

steps.title: Convert the whole number into a fraction.
steps.content: Convert the whole number into a fraction. To do this, simply add a denominator of 1 {\displaystyle 1} to your whole number. Remember, the denominator tells you how many parts are needed to make a whole, and the numerator tells you how many parts you have . [1] X Research source So, putting the whole number over 1 tells us we have that many whole parts. For example, 2 + 3 4 {\displaystyle 2+{\frac {3}{4}}} . This will now become 2 1 + 3 4 {\displaystyle {\frac {2}{1}}+{\frac {3}{4}}} .

steps.title: Multiply the denominators to find a common denominator.
steps.content: Multiply the denominators to find a common denominator. Before we can add the fractions, they need to match denominators, Jia says. There are two ways to do this. First, we could find the least common denominator . [2] X Research source Or, we could simply multiply the two denominators together, which is often easier, so that’s how we’ll do it here. For example, we have 2 1 + 3 4 {\displaystyle {\frac {2}{1}}+{\frac {3}{4}}} . When we multiply the denominators together, we get 1 ∗ 4 {\displaystyle 1*4} , which is 4 {\displaystyle 4} , so that’s our new common denominator.

steps.title: Convert both numerators to match the new denominator.
steps.content: Convert both numerators to match the new denominator. Now, we need to make sure that our fractions still have the same value after we changed our denominator. To do this, we multiply the numerator of each fraction by the same number that we multiplied the denominator by. [3] X Research source For the first fraction, 2 1 {\displaystyle {\frac {2}{1}}} , we multiplied the denominator by 4 {\displaystyle 4} , so we’ll do the same to the numerator: 2 ∗ 4 = 8 {\displaystyle 2*4=8} . Put this new numerator over the new denominator to get 8 4 {\displaystyle {\frac {8}{4}}} . Since 3 4 {\displaystyle {\frac {3}{4}}} already has a numerator of 4 {\displaystyle 4} , we don’t have to multiply the numerator by anything—we can leave it as it is.

steps.title: Add both fractions.
steps.content: Add both fractions. Now that you've got two fractions of the same denominator, we can add both fractions' numerators together, leaving the denominator as it is. [4] X Research source For example, now we have 8 4 + 3 4 {\displaystyle {\frac {8}{4}}+{\frac {3}{4}}} . Adding these, we get 11 4 {\displaystyle {\frac {11}{4}}} .

steps.title: Divide the numerator by the denominator to simplify your answer.
steps.content: Divide the numerator by the denominator to simplify your answer. We’re left with an improper fraction, but we can’t stop there. Now, we convert our improper fraction to a mixed fraction just by dividing the numerator into the denominator, Jia says. Doing this can get you either a mixed fraction or a whole number. Both would be correct depending on the numerator and denominator divisibility. For example, our final answer was 11 4 {\displaystyle {\frac {11}{4}}} : 11 / 4 = 2 {\displaystyle 11/4=2} , with 3 {\displaystyle 3} parts left over as the remainder. The whole number stands alone, and we put the remainder over our new denominator to find the fraction part of our mixed number. So the answer is now 2 3 4 {\displaystyle 2{\frac {3}{4}}} .

steps.title: Convert both mixed numbers into improper fractions.
steps.content: Convert both mixed numbers into improper fractions. Before we can add mixed numbers together, we need to make them improper fractions . Multiply each whole number by the denominator of the fraction that it’s next to. Then, add the product to that fraction’s numerator to get the new improper fraction. [5] X Research source For example, say we want to add 3 1 2 + 2 3 4 {\displaystyle 3{\frac {1}{2}}+2{\frac {3}{4}}} : Starting with the first fraction, we multiply 2 ∗ 3 = 6 {\displaystyle 2*3=6} . Then, add this to the fraction’s numerator: 6 + 1 = 7 {\displaystyle 6+1=7} . Put this number over the denominator to get 7 2 {\displaystyle {\frac {7}{2}}} . Do the same operations with the second fraction, 2 3 4 {\displaystyle 2{\frac {3}{4}}} . 4 ∗ 2 = 8 {\displaystyle 4*2=8} . Then, 8 + 3 = 11 {\displaystyle 8+3=11} , so our second improper fraction is 11 4 {\displaystyle {\frac {11}{4}}} . Now, we have the equation 7 2 + 11 4 {\displaystyle {\frac {7}{2}}+{\frac {11}{4}}} .

steps.title: Multiply the denominators to find a common denominator.
steps.content: Multiply the denominators to find a common denominator. Now we have two improper fractions, but before we can add them together, Jia reminds us that we need to make their denominators match. We can do this either by finding a least common multiple, or just by multiplying the denominators together, which, in this case, is easier. [6] X Research source We’re working with the fractions 7 2 {\displaystyle {\frac {7}{2}}} and 11 4 {\displaystyle {\frac {11}{4}}} , so multiply the denominators: 2 ∗ 4 = 8 {\displaystyle 2*4=8} . This means 8 {\displaystyle 8} is our new common denominator.

steps.title: Convert both numerators to match the new common denominator.
steps.content: Convert both numerators to match the new common denominator. We have a common denominator now, but we need to make sure our fractions still have the same value as before. Multiply the numerator of each fraction by the same number that we multiplied each denominator by when we found the common denominator. [7] X Research source For 7 2 {\displaystyle {\frac {7}{2}}} , we multiplied the denominator, 2 {\displaystyle 2} by 4 {\displaystyle 4} , so do the same to the numerator: 7 ∗ 4 = 28 {\displaystyle 7*4=28} . Place this new numerator over the new denominator to get 28 8 {\displaystyle {\frac {28}{8}}} . Our second fraction is 11 4 {\displaystyle {\frac {11}{4}}} and we multiplied the denominator, 4 {\displaystyle 4} , by 2 {\displaystyle 2} . Multiply the numerator by 2 as well: 11 ∗ 2 = 22 {\displaystyle 11*2=22} . Put this over the denominator to get 22 8 {\displaystyle {\frac {22}{8}}} . Now, we’re working with the equation 28 8 + 22 8 {\displaystyle {\frac {28}{8}}+{\frac {22}{8}}} .

steps.title: Add the numerators together.
steps.content: Add the numerators together. Now, we have a simple equation, and both denominators match, so all we need to do is add the numerators together and put the sum over the common denominator to find our answer: [8] X Research source 28 + 22 = 50 {\displaystyle 28+22=50} , our new improper fraction is 50 8 {\displaystyle {\frac {50}{8}}} .

steps.title: Convert the improper fraction into a mixed number with division.
steps.content: Convert the improper fraction into a mixed number with division. We’re not done yet! We can’t leave our answer as an improper fraction—we need to simplify it. To do this, Jia reminds us that we just divide the numerator by the denominator. The number we get is the whole number in our improper fraction, and any remainder is the numerator of our leftover fraction. 50 / 8 = 6 {\displaystyle 50/8=6} , with 2 {\displaystyle 2} left over. That means we have 6 wholes, and 2 parts, so our improper fraction is 6 2 8 {\displaystyle 6{\frac {2}{8}}} . Then, the fraction in our mixed number can be simplified : 2 8 = 1 4 {\displaystyle {\frac {2}{8}}={\frac {1}{4}}} . So, our final answer is 6 1 4 {\displaystyle 6{\frac {1}{4}}} .
